name: Ronith
comment info:
1. I notice that the Black death rate is higher than the white death rate in general for most diseases.
2. I wonder why there is such a big difference and how other races are comparing to white and black.
3. This has a negative impact on my community because I know that there are many people that are not white in my area and I am concerned for how well we will be cared for when it comes to these diseases.
4. This graph displays that black people are having considerably higher mortality rates compared to white people. A catchy headline would be "Is the Health Care System Biased? Black Mortality Rates for Diseases Higher than White Rates."

name: Anuska
comment info:
1. I notice that the mortality rate for black people is significantly higher than the rate for white people. The leading cause of death for black people is heart disease, while the leading cause of death for white people is lung disease. Additionally, the graph is not specific about anything but the race. 
2. I wonder why there is such a big difference between the two, and how those would compare to the mortality rates of a different race such as Asians.
3. This impacts me and my community because how less white people die from causes compared to black people makes me worried that the same may go for my race and that the healthcare system won't treat me and people I know who aren't white as well as they could be.
4. The graph is showing the high differences between white and black people's mortality rates, and this graph was most likely used in an article about racism, either in the healthcare system or in general. A title could be "Racism in America's Health Care System".

name: DeAnthony Alston
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
Heart disease has the highest mortality for black people while lung disease has the highest mortality rate for white people. The graph does not show the sex or age of the people affected. 
2. What do you wonder?
Cancer is not specified so I wonder if they broke up the different types of cancer which group would have a higher mortality rate
3. What impact does this have on you and your community?
The graph can lead to researchers focusing on why there are higher death rates for certain diseases, maybe because the way doctors treat patients or there is something on a biological level. Whatever it is, researchers can help lower mortality rates. 
4. What's going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.
The graph shows the difference between mortality rates for some diseases including cancer, lung disease, and pneumonia. A title for this graph could be: Deadly differences in disease death rates.

name: Nico
comment info: I notice that most of the causes of death that have a higher mortality rate for black people are things that can be treated, whereas the ones that are higher for white people (and the discrepancy is huge, bars on the right extend MUCH further than bars on the left) are things that a lot of people die from even with treatment. name: Joseph Mendoza
comment info:
1. I notice that the axis is showcasing two sides: 10 white deaths per 100k versus 40 black deaths per 100k. This difference automatically tells me that there are more black people dying then there are white people dying. I also see that the bar towards the black death side is a lot thicker, and shows more causes of death in comparison to white people. 
2. I wonder as to why black people face more common illnesses like heart disease, diabetes, and cancer while white people have rarer diseases Parkinson's and Alzheimer's. I feel like there is room to discuss whether black people have these causes of death because of racial prejudice and not having access to medical care. 
3. This impacts me and my community in the sense that my community is predominantly people of color. Since a large portion of them are black, it makes me want to know if the poorer living conditions are at fault for black people's lack of medical access or if there is a systematic racial issue, or both. 
4. The graph is showing the differences in the amount of white people versus black people dying and the causes of deaths that are associated. Possible headline: "US Americans: What are Common Causes of Deaths for Different Groups?"

replies.comment info: I think that white Americans suffer from Parkinson's and Alzheimer's more than African Americans because African Americans are dying more from things that happen a little bit earlier in life, white Americans are getting things that happen later in life, like Alzheimer's.

name: Amber
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
Heart disease has the highest mortality for black people while lung disease has the highest mortality rate for white people. The graph does not show the sex or age of the people affected. 
2. What do you wonder?

The graph can lead to researchers focusing on why there are higher death rates for certain diseases, maybe because the way doctors treat patients or there is something on a biological level. Whatever it is, researchers can help lower mortality rates.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Amber --

Thank you for your insightful comments.  

Researchers are studying why the incidence of causes of death vary among ethnic and racial groups.  
If you go to the Reveal toward the bottom of this site, you will see a link to a graph of death by Covid-19 by group.  You can also read why researchers think people are affected differently.  For sure we do not know all of the answers yet.
@Amber I have a feeling that the cancer with highest mortality rate would be lung cancer or skin cancer. It's scary to see how cancer as a whole is the second largest cause of death. That's sad.

name: G. Bonnema
comment info:
I notice that many more black Americans died of heart-related causes such as heart disease or a stroke. I notice that overall the death rate of black Americans is much higher than that of white Americans. I notice that diseases that primarily affect the nervous system (such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's) are a more common death among white Americans. I notice that the cause of death that is homicide is much more common among black Americans which is likely a product of racism. 
I wonder if lung/liver disease is included under cancer and the same for cancer being included under lung/liver disease. I wonder why the cause of death of suicide is more common among white Americans. I wonder why Parkinson's and Alzheimer's and more common amongst white Americans. I wonder why there is such a larger portion of deaths from heart disease in black Americans. I wonder if/how much the quality of healthcare available to black Americans differs from that of white Americans.
A possible title would be "Race and the Deadly Differences it Can Cause".

name: Emma
comment info:
WHAT DO YOU NOTICE?
I notice that black people have a higher death rate on a lot of diseases and white people do not have as high of a death rate on diseases but they have higher death rates on other smaller diseases. 

WHAT DO YOU WONDER?
I wonder if black people have a higher death rate on a lot of things than white people do because they have worse health care. I also wonder why so many white Americans commit suicide. If anything I thought it would be black Americans because they have been treated worse in the past (and sometimes still in the present).

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Emma --

How did you decide that some causes of death were “smaller?”  The graph does show this but no one has pointed it out yet.  Would you share with us what you noticed about the relative size of causes?

Interesting wonder about suicide.  Maybe there are other factors that affect those who commit suicide.

name: Shakira Kashif
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
I noticed that Black Americans have a higher death rate than white Americans. The highest death rate for Black Americans is Heart Disease and for white Americans it is Lung Disease. I also notice that Homicide is a larger reason for death rates in Black Americans.

2. What do you wonder?
I wonder why Suicide rates are so high for white Americans. I also wonder why the government hasn't done anything to resolve the issue of such high death rates especially in Black Americans. Do Americans not have access to treatments for these diseases health issues etc.. I wonder if racism is a cause of why so many homicides occur mainly towards Black Americans.

3. What impact does this have on you and your community?
This largely Impacts me and my community. There is a lot of racial disparity in healthcare. Stereotypes of Black people having higher a pain tolerance is probably one of the many reasons Black Americans are more prone to dying of such causes as seen in the graph. Doctors do not treat Black Americans the same way as white Americans. 
4. What's going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.
This graph shows the cause of deaths in white and Black Americans and the death rate. I catchy headline would be "The hidden racism behind Mortality"

replies.name: G
replies.comment info: @Shakira Kashif I also wonder why there is a higher rate of suicide in white Americans and agree that something needs to be done regarding the difference in treatment that is easily racist I thought your title was clever and addresses the issue very well.

Good evening, @Shakira Kashif --

I regret that we did not have this headline by deadline.  If we had, we would have published it and given you a shout-out.  

This graph came from an opinion article and not a news article.  Below is the link to the article.  There, you will read from experts on why there is this gap in mortality.  They mention your reasons plus several more.  If you search for the article that is cited as the source, you can read about mortality by race from a scholarly journal article.

Keep noticing and wondering!

replies.comment info:
HI, @Mohamed M --

Thank you for your noticing.  Take another look at the label across the top of the graph.  Are the units numbers or something else?  What does “per 100K” mean?  Now, what do you notice?

This graph came from a New York Times opinion article, not a news article.  Below in the Reveal is the link to the article.  There, you will read why experts believe there is this gap in mortality.  (If you search for the article that is cited as the source, you can read about mortality by race from a scholarly journal article.)   You can read about many factors that people believe contribute to this gap between Black and white mortality by cause of death.  Talk to your family and friends about this.  Many people are working to close this gap.  Maybe you can work on this in the future.

people of color. I wonder what the death rate comparison would be between the two.

name: Kaitlin

name: Sabrina
comment info:
The first thing our group noticed was how heart disease predominantly affects Black Americans more than white Americans. We wondered what factors played into this information to create such a gap between the two- location, average income, etc. 

After examining this graph, we believe that Black Americans have a harder time obtaining resources that white Americans are exposed to, especially when it comes to medical care. Maybe if there was access to health care or medical aid in this region, this graph will look different. They have definitely been marginalized when it comes to their mortality rate because it’s affected their community for years. It shows how there's an imbalance when it comes to medical care. Our catch phrase would be "The Deathly Gap".

name: IMEG
comment info: What we notice is there is a higher black mortality rate. The graph consists of more diseases on the black side than the white side. What we wonder is why there is such a discrepancy between the death rates on either side. We wonder if this has to do with where these two races prominently live and the access to health care that they have. It is eye-opening to see the differences in mortality rates from the leading causes of death between white and black people. There needs to be an equal opportunity for receiving health care no matter your race or social class. Hopefully, this topic continues to get the attention that it demands, and someday soon we will see a change in the discrepancies. A good title for this graph might be "Differences in Death Rates: The Race Gap."

replies.name: A

name: Halimo
comment info:
Our headline: Racial Inequality, even in death. 
I notice that in total on this graph there is a higher death rate for black people than there is for white people. I also notice that there is an extremely high number of deaths from heart disease for black people.  The other 4 big categories for black deaths are diabetes, cancer, homicide, and kidney disease. The death rate shown on this graph in total for white people is much smaller than black people. The biggest killer for white people is Lung disease and Suicide follows. One thing that stood out about white deaths is that there is a large number of deaths caused by accidents and that isn’t even a category for black people. I wonder why there was such a large gap between deaths white people and black people in the area of heart disease and cancer and how much institutional racism plays a part in it? I also wonder why white people have a higher rate of dying from lung disease and suicide. This has an impact on our community because the largest amount of black people are dying from heart disease or cancer while the largest amount of white people are dying from lung disease and suicide. This also has an impact on our community because there is a higher amount of deaths for black people than white people. This could possibly show that black people aren’t getting the same medical treatment as white people.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Halimo Thank you for your observations. I appreciate how you were able to identify specific categories in which the differences in death rates between the two racial groups are particularly extreme. How could you tell?

name: Ashley
comment info: We noticed that Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s death was a majority of whites while the vast majority of deaths due to heart disease was African Americans. We also noticed that the African Americans have a higher death rate than whites which makes us wonder why that is. We wonder why African Americans have a higher death rate than whites. Part of our inference is that we noticed African Americans have a high death rate with diabetes, so we raised the question, do they die of diabetes more often because insulin prices are out of the roof? We also wondered what this graph would look like if healthcare was more accessible for African Americans since one of their common deaths is the flu, a virus most people overcome. We lastly wondered why whites are suffering from things such as lung disease, Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, etc. and not things such as the flu, heart disease, diabetes, etc.

replies.name: T
replies.comment info: @Ashley I like how you wonder why African Americans have a higher death rate and makes us wonder.

name: Brian Samuel
comment info:
Upon analyzing the graph, our team noticed the disproportionate majorities between race in the top 15 causes of death. Furthermore, we observed that Black deaths are mostly caused by heart disease and cancer, while white deaths are mostly caused by lung disease and a mix of other health complications. As a result of these findings, we wondered why the black death rate is so much higher in heart disease, cancer, diabetes, strokes, homicide as well as why are there more white deaths for lung disease. Could this have a correlation with the amount of whites that smoke compared to blacks? Based on these questions, we wonder if a lack of access to healthcare with a certain race may be the cause of the differences in death rates. The information presented in this graph shows the important health complications we believe doctors and scientists should be working on more based on race. We think this graph shows how some people are more likely to die from certain causes because of their race and we believe the impact of this information on our community can shed some light onto solutions for the problems this graph might represent.
Headline: If we were to choose a headline for this graph, it would be “The Divides in Death” or “The Deathly Divide.”

replies.comment info:
HI, @Brian Samuel --

There are many reasons that have been proposed and studied about what cause this difference including systemic issues (as the article expresses), genetics, environmental conditions or personal behavior?  

By Friday, we will reveal the link to the article that included this graph and other graphs.  What risk factors does it advance?  Also, read some of the comments made by New York Times readers, especially the Reader and NYT Picks.  What do others believe the reasons for this gap?  

What would you suggest that soon-to-be President Biden should focus on to greatly reduce this gap?

replies.name: j
replies.comment info: @Brian Samuel i agree with your comment about not everyone having access to healthcare. this may be why the gap is so large.

name: Arthur
comment info:
Death rate disparities are more dramatic than the graph indicates given the relative size of the two populations compared.  The number of white suicides is more than ten times black suicides though the ratio of the populations is smaller than that.

Does the disproportionate number of deaths from cancer among blacks include cancers of the liver?  Is the larger number of liver-related deaths among whites attributable to liver diseases other than cancer?

The information from which the data the graph represents is the basis for decisions about medical care and public health policy.

Causes of Death Ranked by Race

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Arthur --

Thank you for your insightful comments.

You bring up a good mathematical point -- these statistics on the horizontal axis are rates -- number of deaths per 100,000 population for each group.  This graph does not show the number of deaths by each group.  

This article is an opinion piece which is focused on the gap between white and Black deaths.  Which statistic better describes the disparity -- rate or number?

name: Will
comment info:
1. I notice that African Americans make up the vast majority of deaths by heart disease. Whites make up the majority of Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s deaths.

2. I wonder if these complication are due to the often poor and unhealthy diet of many economically disadvantaged African Americans. This is because unhealthy foods and typically more affordable in our consumer climate.

3. This affects me because as a white person, I am fortunate to have access to health foods but I am also susceptible to neurological diseases and complications caused by smoking and alcohol.

4. Headline: 
Death by Socioeconomic Factors

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Will --

You write that “African Americans make up the vast majority of deaths by heart disease.”  

Reread the labels on the axes.  Is it number?  No, it’s “per 100k.”  Per 100k means deaths per 100,000 people.  And, here, it means the population for either white or Black people.  Now, using this information, what can you say about the rate of death?  And, the number of deaths?  Pleas share your thoughts.

Also, your headline is “Death by Socioeconomic Factors.”  What other factors could affect the outcomes from these causes?   By Friday, we will reveal the link to the opinion article that included this graph and other graphs.  What risk factors does this article advance?  Also, read some of the comments made by New York Times readers, especially the Reader and NYT Picks.  What do others believe are the reasons for this gap?

name: Paul Coffield
comment info:
I notice that this graph shows major causes of deaths in the United States, and how these causes of death relate to race (Black people and white people specifically). Black people have significantly higher death rates from heart disease, diabetes, cancer, stroke, and several other causes of death than white people. White people seem to have slightly higher death rates for a few causes of death (lung disease, suicude, accidents, and Alzheimer’s). I wonder if Black people have higher rates of disease due to the racism embedded into America’s food systems. In my home city of Memphis, for example, majority Black neighborhoods are kept from accessing healthy foods and all of the grocery stores are located in majority white neighborhoods. Without access to proper nutrition, people can fall victim to a slew of diseases.

This impacts my community heavily because I live in an extremely diverse yet segregated city where white people are provided with more resources on average than Black people. This graph fuels my anger towards this unfair system by demonstrating how this inequality affects health and can end lives prematurely. 

Headline: Inequality in Life, Inequality in Death.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Paul Coffield Paul, your headline idea is really good, if i were reading a newspaper that would definitely catch my attention. As well, your comment as a whole is extremely well-spoken

Your headline is terrific!
